Message.Title: All the President, VP, all Congressmen and all Politicians must attend SA
Message.Msg: SPENDAHOLICS ANYNONMOUS (THEY FIRST HAVE TO ADMIT THEY HAVE A PROBLEM!!!) It is humorous that all the sequester talk is framed in the context of spending restraint and fiscal prudence. It’s hard to identify where this so-called spending restraint is manifesting itself. When you look at the actual data, not the empty rhetoric, the sequester is hardly the case of fiscal Armageddon we were led to believe. To be clear, anything mandated by CONgress and the president reeks of self-interest. This may not have been the best way to cut the military budget, or federal spending overall. But given the current climate, it may be the only feasible way to cut spending. Let’s face, it isn’t going to get any easier in the future. The incumbent politicians need to protect their pork! However you calculate the spending cuts, and however uneven they may be, the reality is that the sequester at least moves the ball in the right direction. By reducing the government spending share of gross domestic product, the sequester is pro-growth. Even still, the actual percentage of spending cuts relative to GDP is extremely small. In the year to date period of the past four fiscal years, starting October 1 and going through the current day in March, the current year has seen the issuance of exactly $635 billion in Federal Debt, which as of Friday crossed the "psychological barrier" of $16.7 trillion. This is the second highest cumulative debt issuance in one fiscal year, surpassing both 2010 and 2011, and lower only compared to the $726.7 billion raked up in Fiscal 2012. In the meantime, it may be time for a meeting. “Hello, my name is the Unite States, and I’m a spen

Message.Title: Bid $11.92
Message.Msg: Well...been waiting on the p/b in the finny's..it would figure that if the likes of C and such, who had soared in prior session while BAC stayed flat, began to p/b that BAC would suffer proportionally as well. C's down over a buck and BAC is where it is. In the last 30minutes they've used ~14.5M shares to dive the bid here. I've opened an initial buy side trading tranche in C a few minutes ago (at ~$46.54), and just did the same with BAC at this line. I will stair-step additions at target points should the slide continue apace It's a trade so I'm just looking for (my) usual 10pennies...there's a reason some view the likes of C/BAC/MS and others as ATM's. This is why. Their intraday volume and volatility are tailor made for trading....and the manipulation by Algo's, HFT's and the rest, whose profit targets are typically intraday in orientation, are screamingly apparent....all you can do is play along.

Topic.Title: BAC Yesterday, Today, & Tomorrow

Message.Msg: BAC should be at $30 by Dec/2014-Dec/2015. Based on too much extensive analysis to post here. Suffice it to say, earnings are expected to be at $2.75/share X 12 P/E = $33. Also, Banks tend to sell at 2-2.5 times book value doing good times. BAC will earn $1 in 2013 and $1.40 in 2014. Current Book value is $20.25 + $1 (2013), + $1.40 (2014) = $22.65 X 1.5 Book Value = $34. Take your pick both analysis leads to plus $30 in less than 2 years. And do not make the mistake that this stock can make a huge run up, fast.

Message.Title: Here's what happened...
Message.Msg: Friday the shorts/hedgies that wrote $12 options fought BAC back to $12 and a fraction on Friday to have the $12 options expire near worthless...They shorted it down to the close of $12.06 Friday...Now they needed to cover those shorts so they held it down today to cover and make a little profit...They will now go long, and when they accumulate enough, will let it take off with the news expected later in the week...IMHO...

Topic.Title: BAC Yesterday, Today, & Tomorrow

Message.Msg: This is basically the same numbers I came up with. Their are several unknowns that give me a wide range of possibilities. A historic rule was to buy a bank when it got near 1X book, and lighten up if it got over 2X book. To get to historic norms will take time, bac is below book so should be bought. 12PE is actually a low pe for bank stocks, and many have an even lower pe than 12 currently. The market will dictate if we get to historic norms, but there is a century of data that says we are in one of a handful of abnormally low bank valuations. Bac could stay under 20, or go back to near 50. 2.75 x 18 pe, the current pe of many food stocks.

Zkie: Of course it is. And I feel your pain. But it is what it is. You cannot change it; especially if the big boys/girls in partnership with regulatory authorities (heh) ain't allowing it. But to be aware is to give yourself the potential to play it "properly." If you know the table is slanting...and you know which way it's slanted....you just got to sit on the side that favors the table is all you can do....and get some of the scraps as allowed by those "titans of industry and finance." Properly played those scraps can be sizable. -VBG-

Message.Title: CONVERGING WEDGE FORMED
Message.Msg: I detailed in earlier posts how there were several trendlines in play at the moment. For awhile it was touch and go around $11, but that support held as well as the lower trendline as the price pattern produced bars that touched the trendline for several days without breaking. The next suspected resistance was just struck and the price was rejected from it. To continue along the upward trending parallel channel, this level must be overcome. Keep an eye on it, and when breached would signal a buy. I've put all this discussion on stockineer as well as the charts to illustrate these points, but I wanted to give the brief summary here. Good luck guys and trade wisely.
hey "tomfoolery" I recognize that rant!

Topic.Title: We need good news Thursday for sure

Message.Msg: First of all, the Motley Fools are Pure Ameteurs. Second, BAC is expected to have earnings of $1 in 2013. The Fed may allow dividends based on that fact. Three, the banks were allowed to submit dividend request and Fed would give them a chance to am end if Fed disallowed request.

Topic.Title: We need good news Thursday for sure

Message.Msg: BAC has been very active in their attempts to repair the stock price, unlike companies such as Apple who give off the vibe that they don't care about their stock price. Earnings this year may be low but like the above post, they are low because of non-recurring charges and the real income is expected to be significantly higher. I think that we'll see a decent buy back, and a decent dividend, not on the high side and not on the low side, for these reasons combined. I'm looking at a div that is over 1.5% as good, so a yearly total over 16 cents (or quarterly 4c) and several billion buy back. This would indicate they are on an upward trend. Too much of a dividend is a bad sign because of the high number of shares outstanding. Too little is a prob because of investor interest/sentiment.

Topic.Title: We need good news Thursday for sure

Message.Msg: We should get 16 cents a year or in the very least 12 cents dividend. I estimate $1.50 eps for 2014. Then we could have dividends of 32-40 cents a year.

Message.Title: How Does Spam Work?
Message.Msg: So you got these people who make these posts trying to get you to click on a site. You can tell which ones they are because they'll get 'thumbs up' well into double digits where the ordinary post only gets a few at most. For awhile, the poster's names were women. Now they are full men's names like smithlawrence or lawrencesmith. Obviously, these people get paid for posting these things and they or others get paid for the thumbs up (unless that's some robo function). How do they make money? Who pays them? How do I get in on this scam? As much money as I lost four and five years ago, I'm still behind the eight ball. Would love to make some by posting foolishness. I post stupid things as it is now and get paid nothing.

Topic.Title: We need good news Thursday for sure

Message.Msg: "Citgroup has been steadily increasing their profitability in the last few years. Going in to next year, their earnings are predicted to be $4.60 per share. An additional 12% is expected for 2014. This earnings coupled with a potential future dividend and a stock repurchase make Citigroup a great company to look at. Bank of America investors can expect a drastic increase in earnings per share in 2013. Analysts expect $1.00 per share in earnings next year with an additional 29% increase going in to 2014." You already voiced your opinion about Motly Fool and I did cut and paste this from one of their articles today. I WANT you to be correct but I simply don't think you are. C is expected to have similar earnings (adjusted for having 3.04B outstanding shares). They are buying back less than 2 billion worth of shares with no dividend increase. For the most part I agree with you, I just think you are a year early in your numbers. I think we gain about 6.00 per share for the next 3 years. My "guess" for thursday is a "MAX" .16 dividend and 3 billion worth of buybacks anounced (and I worry I am high in my guess). Just my opinion, I would prefer you being better than I at predicting the future.
